member.summary: Opens a stream for reading the specified asset. Derived classes can replace this to implement pack files or asset compression.
member.param: The name of the asset being read.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.ReadAsset``1(System.String,System.Action{System.IDisposable})
member.summary: Low-level worker method that reads asset data.
member.param: The name of the asset to be loaded from disk.

Delegate function for handling the disposition of assets. If recordDisposableObject is null, the default lifespan tracking and management is used, so unloading or disposing of the content manager frees everything that has been loaded through it. If recordDisposableObject specifies a valid delegate, that delegate is used instead of the default lifespan tracking and is called every time the loader encounters a type that implements System.IDisposable. You must use your own code to unload assets loaded in this fashion, since ContentManager's ContentManager.Unload method will not be aware of them.
member.returns: Returns the loaded asset.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager.Unload
member.summary: Disposes all data that was loaded by this ContentManager.

member.returns: The service provider associated with the ContentManager.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.ContentManager
member.summary: The ContentManager is the run-time component which loads managed objects from the binary files produced by the design time content pipeline. It also manages the lifespan of the loaded objects, disposing the content manager will also dispose any assets which are themselves System.IDisposable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.ContentImporterAttribute.CacheImportedData
member.summary: Gets and sets the caching of the content during importation.
member.returns: If true, imported content is cached in an intermediate file (managed by XNA). By default, caching is not enabled. Caching provides significantly faster iteration times when changing the processing code for a file format. A good example would be a third-party digital content creation (DCC) tool that needs to execute before importation can occur. However, caching is not appropriate for all importersfor example, caching bulky content that is quick to import, such as bitmap images.

member.summary: Specifies the target output (of type SurfaceFormat) of the texture processor.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Processors.TextureProcessorOutputFormat.Color
member.summary: The SurfaceFormat value, of the input TextureContent object, is converted to Color by the processor. Typically used for 2D graphics and overlays.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Processors.TextureProcessorOutputFormat.DxtCompressed
member.summary: The SurfaceFormat value, of the input TextureContent object, is converted to an appropriate DXT compression by the processor. If the input texture contains fractional alpha values, it is converted to DXT5 format (8 bits per texel); otherwise it is converted to DXT1 (4 bits per texel). This conversion reduces the resource's size on the graphics card. Typically used for 3D textures such as 3D model textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Content.Pipeline.Processors.TextureProcessorOutputFormat.NoChange
member.summary: The SurfaceFormat value, of the input TextureContent object, is not changed by the processor. Typically used for textures processed by an external tool.

member.summary: Indicates that one bounding volume completely contains the other.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.ContainmentType.Disjoint
member.summary: Indicates there is no overlap between the bounding volumes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveContinuity
member.summary: Defines the continuity of CurveKeys on a Curve.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveContinuity.Smooth
member.summary: Interpolation can be used between this CurveKey and the next.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveContinuity.Step
member.summary: Interpolation cannot be used between this CurveKey and the next. Specifying a position between the two points returns this point.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType
member.summary: Defines how the value of a Curve will be determined for positions before the first point on the Curve or after the last point on the Curve.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Constant
member.summary: The Curve will evaluate to its first key for positions before the first point in the Curve and to the last key for positions after the last point.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Cycle
member.summary: Positions specified past the ends of the curve will wrap around to the opposite side of the Curve.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.CycleOffset
member.summary: Positions specified past the ends of the curve will wrap around to the opposite side of the Curve. The value will be offset by the difference between the values of the first and last CurveKey multiplied by the number of times the position wraps around. If the position is before the first point in the Curve, the difference will be subtracted from its value; otherwise, the difference will be added.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Linear
member.summary: Linear interpolation will be performed to determine the value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveLoopType.Oscillate
member.summary: Positions specified past the ends of the Curve act as an offset from the same side of the Curve toward the opposite side.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent
member.summary: Specifies different tangent types to be calculated for CurveKey points in a Curve.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent.Flat
member.summary: A Flat tangent always has a value equal to zero.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent.Linear
member.summary: A Linear tangent at a CurveKey is equal to the difference between its CurveKey.Value and the Value of the preceding or succeeding CurveKey.For example, in Curve MyCurve, where i is greater than zero and (i + 1) is less than the total number of CurveKeys in MyCurve, the linear CurveKey.TangentIn of MyCurve.Keys[i] is equal to: ( MyCurve.Keys[i].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Value )Similarly, the linear CurveKey.TangentOut is equal to: ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i].Value.)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.CurveTangent.Smooth
member.summary: A Smooth tangent smooths the inflection between a CurveKey.TangentIn and CurveKey.TangentOut by taking into account the values of both neighbors of the CurveKey.The smooth CurveKey.TangentIn of MyCurve.Keys[i] is equal to: ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Value ) * ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Position ) / ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i-1].Position ) ) )Similarly, the smooth CurveKey.TangentOut is equal to: ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Value - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Value ) * ( ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i].Position ) / ( MyCurve.Keys[i + 1].Position - MyCurve.Keys[i - 1].Position ) ) )

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.PlaneIntersectionType
member.summary: Describes the intersection between a plane and a bounding volume.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.PlaneIntersectionType.Back
member.summary: There is no intersection, and the bounding volume is in the negative half-space of the Plane.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.PlaneIntersectionType.Front
member.summary: There is no intersection, and the bounding volume is in the positive half-space of the Plane.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.PlaneIntersectionType.Intersecting
member.summary: The Plane is intersected.

member.returns: The ambient light color of this effect. Valid values are between 0 and 1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.DiffuseColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the diffuse color of this effect material. Value takes 0 to 1.
member.returns: The diffuse color of this effect material. Valid values are between 0 and 1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.DirectionalLight0
member.summary: Gets the first directional light for this effect.
member.returns: A directional light for this effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.DirectionalLight1
member.summary: Gets the second directional light for this effect.
member.returns: A directional light for this effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.DirectionalLight2
member.summary: Gets the third directional light for this effect.
member.returns: A directional light for this effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.EmissiveColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the emissive color of the effect material.
member.returns: The emissive color of the effect material. Valid values are between 0 and 1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.FogColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the fog color for this effect.
member.returns: The fog color for this effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.FogEnabled
member.summary: Enables fog for this effect.
member.returns: true to enable fog; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.FogEnd
member.summary: Gets or sets the ending distance of fog.
member.returns: Fog end distance specified as a positive value.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.FogStart
member.summary: Gets or sets the fog start distance.
member.returns: Fog start distance specified as a positive value. This distance is expressed in world space coordinates.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.LightingEnabled
member.summary: Enables lighting for this effect.
member.returns: true to enable lighting; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.PreferPerPixelLighting
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating that per-pixel lighting should be used if it is available for the current adapter. Per-pixel lighting is available if a graphics adapter supports Pixel Shader Model 2.0.
member.returns: true to use per-pixel lighting if it is available; false to disable per-pixel lighting. The default value is true. When Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.PreferPerPixelLighting is true, if the graphics adapter does not support a minimum of Pixel Shader Model 2.0, BasicEffect will automatically fall-back to per-vertex lighting. When Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.PreferPerPixelLighting is false, per-vertex lighting is used regardless of whether per-pixel lighting is supported by the graphics adapter.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.Projection
member.summary: Gets or sets the projection matrix.
member.returns: The projection matrix.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.SpecularColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the specular color of this effect material.
member.returns: The specular color of this effect material. Valid values are between 0 and 1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.SpecularPower
member.summary: Gets or sets the specular power of this effect material.
member.returns: The specular power of this effect material.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.TextureEnabled
member.summary: Enables textures for this effect.
member.returns: true to enable textures; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.Texture
member.summary: Gets or sets a texture to be applied by this effect.
member.returns: Texture to be applied by this effect.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.VertexColorEnabled
member.summary: Enables use vertex colors for this effect.
member.returns: true to enable vertex colors; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.View
member.summary: Gets or sets the view matrix.
member.returns: The view matrix.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect.World
member.summary: Gets or sets the world matrix.
member.returns: The world matrix.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BasicEffect
member.summary: Represents shader model 1.1 Effect that has optional support for vertex colors, texturing, and lighting.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilationFailedException.#ctor(System.String,System.Exception)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the CompilationFailedException class with a specified error message and a reference to the inner exception that is the cause of this exception. .
member.param: A message that describes the error.
The exception that is the cause of the current exception. If the inner parameter is not a null reference, the current exception is raised in a catch block that handles the inner exception.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of this class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthStencilBuffer.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.MultiSampleType,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the DepthStencilBuffer class, specifying the multisample type and quality.
member.param: The graphics device that will display the depth stencil buffer.
Width, in pixels, of the depth stencil buffer. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferWidth to get the current screen width.
Height, in pixels, of the depth stencil buffer. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferHeight to get the current screen height.
The format of the data to be placed in this depth stencil buffer. Use GraphicsAdapter.CheckDepthStencilMatch to determine if a particular depth format is usable in a render target.
The levels of full-scene multisampling that the device can apply. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleType to get the MultiSampleType of the back buffer.
The number of quality stops available for a given multisample type. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleQuality to get the multisample quality of the back buffer.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthStencilBuffer.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the DepthStencilBuffer class.
member.param: The graphics device that will display the depth stencil buffer.
Width, in pixels, of the depth stencil buffer. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferWidth to get the current screen width.
Height, in pixels, of the depth stencil buffer. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferHeight to get the current screen height.
The format of the data to be placed in this depth stencil buffer. Use GraphicsAdapter.CheckDepthStencilMatch to determine if a particular depth format is usable in a render target.

member.name: E:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthStencilBuffer.ContentLost
member.summary: Occurs when resources are lost (for example, when the current device is lost).

member.name: E:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthStencilBuffer.Disposing
member.summary: Occurs when DepthStencilBuffer.Dispose is called or when this object is finalized and collected by the garbage collector of the Microsoft .NET common language runtime (CLR).

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthStencilBuffer.raise_ContentLost(System.Object,System.EventArgs)
member.summary: Occurs when content is about to be lost on a GraphicsDevice.
member.param: The source of this event.

member.summary: Verifies whether a surface buffer format is available as a specified resource type and can be used as a texture, depth-stencil buffer, render target, or any combination of the three on a device representing the current adapter.

A set of options identifying the behaviors of this surface resource.

member.summary: Verifies whether a depth buffer format is available as a specified resource type and can be used as a texture, depth-stencil buffer, render target, or any combination of the three, on a device representing the current adapter.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsAdapter.CheckDeviceMultiSampleType(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DeviceType,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat,System.Boolean,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.MultiSampleType,System.Int32@)
member.summary: Verifies whether a multisample technique is available on a specified game machine, optionally returning the number of quality stops available for the specified technique.
member.param: The type of device to check.
The format of the surface to be multisampled.
true to inquire about windowed multisampling; false to inquire about full-screen multisampling.
The multisampling technique to test.
Number of quality stops available for a given multisample type; can be null if it is not necessary to return the values.
member.returns: true if the technique is available; false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsAdapter.CheckDeviceType(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DeviceType,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Determines whether a hardware-accelerated device type can be used on the current adapter.
member.param: The type of device to check.
The format of the adapter display mode for which the device type is being checked. For example, some devices operate only in modes of 16 bits per pixel.

Format of the back buffer. This value must be one of the render target formats. GraphicsDevice.DisplayMode can be used to obtain the current format.For windowed applications, the back-buffer format does not need to match the display-mode format if the hardware supports color conversion. The set of possible back-buffer formats is constrained, but the runtime allows any valid back-buffer format to be presented to any desktop format. Additionally, the device must be operable in desktop mode because devices typically do not operate in modes of 8 bits per pixel.Full-screen applications cannot perform color conversion.SurfaceFormat.Unknown is allowed for windowed mode.
true if the device type will be used in windowed mode; false if the device type will be used in full-screen mode.
member.returns: true if the method succeeds and the device can be used on this adapter; false if the method fails. If the method fails, you may check the result code returned by Manager.CheckDeviceTypeResult to determine the specific reason.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.Clear(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ClearOptions,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Color,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Rectangle[])
member.summary: Clears a set of regions to a specified color, clears the depth buffer, and erases the stencil buffer.
member.param: Flags that indicate which surfaces to clear.
Color value to which the render target surface is cleared.

New depth value to store in the depth buffer. This parameter can be in the range of 0.0 through 1.0 (for z-based or w-based depth buffers). A value of 0.0 represents the nearest distance to the viewer; a value of 1.0 represents the farthest distance.
Integer value to store in each stencil-buffer entry. This parameter can be in the range of 0 through 2n1, where n is the bit depth of the stencil buffer.
The regions to clear.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.Clear(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ClearOptions,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector4,System.Single,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Rectangle[])
member.summary: Clears a set of regions to a specified color, clears the depth buffer, and erases the stencil buffer.
member.param: The surfaces to clear.
Color value to which the render target surface is cleared.

New z value that this method stores in the depth buffer. This parameter can be in the range of 0.0 through 1.0 (for z-based or w-based depth buffers). A value of 0.0 represents the nearest distance to the viewer; a value of 1.0 represents the farthest distance.
Integer value to store in each stencil-buffer entry. This parameter can be in the range of 0 through 2n1, where n is the bit depth of the stencil buffer.
The regions to clear.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawIndexedPrimitives(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Renders the specified geometric primitive, based on indexing into an array of vertices.
member.param: Describes the type of primitive to render. PrimitiveType.PointList is not supported with this method.
Offset to add to each vertex index in the index buffer.
Minimum vertex index for vertices used during the call. The minVertexIndex parameter and all of the indices in the index stream are relative to the baseVertex parameter.
A number of vertices used during the call. The first vertex is located at index: baseVertex + minVertexIndex.
Location in the index array at which to start reading vertices.

A number of primitives to render. The number of vertices used is a function of primitiveCount and primitiveType. To determine the maximum number of primitives allowed, check the MaxPrimitiveCount property member of the Capabilities structure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawPrimitives(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Renders a sequence of non-indexed geometric primitives of the specified type from the current set of data input streams.
member.param: Describes the type of primitive to render.
Index of the first vertex to load. Beginning at startVertex, the correct number of vertices is read out of the vertex buffer.

Number of primitives to render. To determine the maximum number of primitives allowed, check GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxPrimitiveCount. The primitiveCount is the number of primitives as determined by the primitive type. If it is a line list, each primitive has two vertices. If it is a triangle list, each primitive has three vertices.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawUserIndexedPrimitives``1(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType,``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int16[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Renders geometric primitives with indexed data specified by the user, specifying an index buffer as an array of type System.Int16.
member.param: Describes the type of primitive to render.
The vertex buffer indexed by indexData.
Offset to add to each vertex index in the index buffer.
Number of vertices used during this call. The first vertex is located at index minVertexIndex.

A list of indices into the vertex buffer, given in the order that you want the vertices to render. Using an array of type System.Int16, which uses 16 bits per element, allows you conserve resources if the index buffer does not require a 32-bit depth array.
Location in the index array at which to start reading vertices.

Number of primitives to render. The maximum number of primitives allowed is determined by checking GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxPrimitiveCount. (The number of indices is a function of the primitive count and the primitive type.)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawUserIndexedPrimitives``1(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType,``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Renders geometric primitives with indexed data specified by the user, specifying an index buffer as an array of type System.Int32.
member.param: Describes the type of primitive to render.
The vertex buffer indexed by indexData.
Offset to add to each vertex index in the index buffer.
Number of vertices used during this call. The first vertex is located at index minVertexIndex.

A list of indices into the vertex buffer, given in the order that you want the vertices to render. Using an array of type System.Int32, which uses 32 bits per element, allows you to index a greater number of elements in the vertex buffer.
Location in the index array at which to start reading vertices.

Number of primitives to render. The maximum number of primitives allowed is determined by checking GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxPrimitiveCount. (The number of indices is a function of the primitive count and the primitive type.)

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.DrawUserPrimitives``1(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType,``0[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Renders the given geometric primitive with data specified by the user.
member.param: Describes the type of primitive to render.
The vertex data.
Offset at which to begin reading vertexData.

Number of primitives to render. The maximum number of primitives allowed is determined by checking GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxPrimitiveCount. The number of indices is a function of primitiveCount and primitiveType.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.Present(System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Specifies the window target for a presentation and presents the display with the contents of the next buffer in the sequence of back buffers owned by the GraphicsDevice.
member.param: Destination window containing the client area that is the target for this presentation. If not specified, this is PresentationParameters.DeviceWindowHandle.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.Present(System.Nullable{Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Rectangle},System.Nullable{Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Rectangle},System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Specifies the window target for a presentation and presents the display with the contents of the next buffer in the sequence of back buffers owned by the GraphicsDevice.
member.param: The source rectangle. If null, the entire source surface is presented. If the rectangle exceeds the source surface, the rectangle is clipped to the source surface. This parameter must be null unless the swap chain was created with SwapEffect.Copy.

The destination rectangle, in window client coordinates. If null, the entire client area is filled. If the rectangle exceeds the destination client area, the rectangle is clipped to the destination client area. This parameter must be null unless the swap chain was created with SwapEffect.Copy.
Destination window containing the client area that is the target for this presentation. If not specified, this is PresentationParameters.DeviceWindowHandle.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice.Present

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.OcclusionQuery.IsSupported
member.summary: Specifies if occlusion queries are supported on the related graphics device.
member.returns: true if occlusion queries are supported; false otherwise.Occlusion queries are always supported on the Xbox 360 platform. Occlusion queries on the Windows platform are dependent upon the abilities of the installed video card.

member.returns: The format of the depth-stencil surface that the device will automatically create.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value specifying how many back buffers to create.
member.returns: The number of back buffers to create. Can be 0, 1, 2, or 3. 0 is considered 1.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.BackBufferFormat
member.summary: Gets or sets the format of the back buffer.
member.returns: The format of the back buffer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.BackBufferHeight
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the height of the new swap chain's back buffer.
member.returns: The height of the back buffer, in pixels.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.BackBufferWidth
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the width of the new swap chain's back buffer.
member.returns: The width of the back buffer, in pixels.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.DeviceWindowHandle
member.summary: Gets or sets the handle to the device window.
member.returns: The handle to the device window.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.EnableAutoDepthStencil
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether Direct3D will manage depth buffers for the application.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.FullScreenRefreshRateInHz
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the rate at which the display adapter will refresh the screen.
member.returns: The refresh rate in hertz, or 0 in windowed mode.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.IsFullScreen
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the application is in full screen mode.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleQuality
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating the multisample quality level.
member.returns: The multisample quality level. The valid range is from 0 to one less than the value returned by GraphicsAdapter.CheckDeviceMultiSampleType.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleType
member.summary: Gets or sets the multisample type.
member.returns: The multisample type. Must be MultiSampleType.None unless PresentationParameters.SwapEffect has been set to SwapEffect.Discard. Multisampling is supported only if PresentationParameters.SwapEffect is SwapEffect.Discard.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.PresentationInterval
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum rate at which the swap chain's back buffers can be presented to the front buffer.
member.returns: The maximum rate at which the swap chain's back buffers can be presented to the front buffer.

member.returns: Presentation flags.

member.returns: Usage flags for the render target.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters.SwapEffect
member.summary: Gets or sets the swap effect.
member.returns: The swap effect to use.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentationParameters
member.summary: Contains presentation parameters.

member.returns: String representation of this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RasterStatus.InVerticalBlank
member.summary: Gets the status of the vertical blank period.
member.returns: true if the raster is in the vertical blank period; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RasterStatus.ScanLine
member.summary: Gets a value that roughly corresponds to the current scan line painted by the raster.
member.returns: Integer that roughly corresponds to the current scan line to set or retrieve.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ToString
member.summary: Retrieves a string representation of this object.
member.returns: String representation of this object.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.AlphaBlendEnable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value to enable alpha-blended transparency. The default value is false.
member.returns: true if alpha-blended transparency is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.AlphaBlendOperation
member.summary: Gets or sets the arithmetic operation applied to separate alpha blending. The default is BlendFunction.Add.
member.returns: A value from the BlendFunction enumeration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.AlphaDestinationBlend
member.summary: Gets or sets the separate alpha channel blending factor. This factor represents a destination value by which to multiply the alpha channel only. The default is Blend.One.
member.returns: A value from the Blend enumeration. BothSourceAlpha and BothInverseSourceAlpha are not supported on Xbox 360.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.AlphaFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparison function for the alpha test. The default is CompareFunction.Always.
member.returns: A member of the CompareFunction enumeration that represents the comparison function to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.AlphaSourceBlend
member.summary: Gets or sets the separate alpha channel blending factor. This factor represents a value by which to multiply the alpha channel only. The default is Blend.One.
member.returns: A value from the Blend enumeration.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.AlphaTestEnable
member.summary: Gets or sets a render state that enables a per-pixel alpha test. The default value is false.
member.returns: true if per-pixel alpha blending is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.BlendFactor
member.summary: Gets or sets the color used for a constant-blend factor during alpha blending. The default is Color.White.
member.returns: The color used for a constant-blend factor during alpha blending.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.BlendFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets a value to select the arithmetic operation to apply to the source and destination pixel components when RenderState.AlphaBlendEnable is set to true. The default is BlendFunction.Add.
member.returns: The blending operation to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ColorWriteChannels1
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables a per-channel write for the render target color buffer. The default value is ColorWriteChannels.None.
member.returns: Value of the ColorWriteChannels enumeration that specifies the color channel to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ColorWriteChannels2
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables a per-channel write for the render target color buffer. The default value is ColorWriteChannels.None.
member.returns: Value of the ColorWriteChannels enumeration that specifies the color channel to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ColorWriteChannels3
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables a per-channel write for the render target color buffer. The default value is ColorWriteChannels.None.
member.returns: Value of the ColorWriteChannels enumeration that specifies the color channel to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ColorWriteChannels
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables a per-channel write for the render target color buffer. The default value is ColorWriteChannels.None.
member.returns: Value of the ColorWriteChannels enumeration that specifies the color channel to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.CounterClockwiseStencilDepthBufferFail
member.summary: Gets or sets the stencil operation to perform if the stencil test passes and the depth-buffer test fails for a counterclockwise triangle. The default is StencilOperation.Keep.
member.returns: The stencil operation to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.CounterClockwiseStencilFail
member.summary: Gets or sets the stencil operation to perform if the stencil test fails for a counterclockwise triangle. The default is StencilOperation.Keep.
member.returns: The stencil operation to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.CounterClockwiseStencilFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparison function to use for counterclockwise stencil tests. The default is CompareFunction.Always.
member.returns: A CompareFunction value indicating which test to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.CounterClockwiseStencilPass
member.summary: Gets or sets the stencil operation to perform if the stencil and z-tests pass for a counterclockwise triangle. The default is StencilOperation.Keep.
member.returns: The stencil operation to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.CullMode
member.summary: Specifies how back-facing triangles are culled, if at all. The default value is CullMode.CounterClockwise.
member.returns: The culling mode to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.DepthBias
member.summary: Sets or retrieves the depth bias for polygons. The default value is 0.
member.returns: Depth bias for polygons.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.DepthBufferEnable
member.summary: Enables or disables depth buffering. The default is true.
member.returns: true if depth buffering is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.DepthBufferFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparison function for the depth-buffer test. The default is CompareFunction.LessEqual
member.returns: Value of a CompareFunction that represents the comparison function to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.DepthBufferWriteEnable
member.summary: Enables or disables writing to the depth buffer. The default is true.
member.returns: true if writing to the depth buffer is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.DestinationBlend
member.summary: Gets or sets the color blending factor. This factor represents a value by which to multiply the destination pixel color before adding it to the source pixel to produce a color that is a blend of the two. The default is Blend.Zero.
member.returns: A Blend factor to set or get for the destination pixel.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FillMode
member.summary: Represents the fill mode. The default is FillMode.Solid.
member.returns: Value of a FillMode that specifies the fill mode to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the fog color. The default value is Color.TransparentBlack.
member.returns: A color that specifies the fog color to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogDensity
member.summary: Gets or sets the fog density for pixel or vertex fog used in exponential fog modes. The default value is 1.0f.
member.returns: Value that represents the fog density to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogEnable
member.summary: Enables or disables fog blending. The default is false.
member.returns: true if fog blending is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogEnd
member.summary: Gets or sets the depth at which pixel or vertex fog effects end for linear fog mode. The default value is 1.0f.
member.returns: Value that represents the ending depth to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogStart
member.summary: Gets or sets the depth at which pixel or vertex fog effects begin for linear fog mode. The default value is 0.0f.
member.returns: Value that represents the beginning depth to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogTableMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the fog formula to use for pixel fog. The default is None.
member.returns: Value of a FogMode that specifies the fog mode to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.FogVertexMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the fog formula to use for vertex fog. The default is FogMode.None.
member.returns: Value of a FogMode that specifies the fog mode to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.MultiSampleAntiAlias
member.summary: Enables or disables multisample antialiasing. The default is true.
member.returns: true to enable multisample antialiasing; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.MultiSampleMask
member.summary: Gets or sets a bitmask controlling modification of the samples in a multisample render target. The default is 0xffffffff.
member.returns: A bitmask value controlling write enables for the samples. Each bit in this mask, starting at the least-significant bit, controls modification of one of the samples in a multisample render target. Thus, for an 8-sample render target, the low byte contains the eight write enables for each of the eight samples. This render state has no effect when rendering to a single sample buffer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.PointSizeMax
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size of point primitives. The default is 64.0f.
member.returns: The maximum size of point primitives. Must be less than or equal to Capabilities.MaxPointSize and greater than or equal to RenderState.PointSizeMin.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.PointSizeMin
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum size of point primitives. The default is 1.0f.
member.returns: The minimum size of point primitives.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.PointSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size to use for point size computation in cases where point size is not specified for each vertex. The default value is the value a driver returns. If a driver returns 0 or 1, the default value is 64, which allows software point size emulation.
member.returns: This value is in world space units.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.PointSpriteEnable
member.summary: Enables or disables full texture mapping on each point. The default is false.
member.returns: true to set texture coordinates of point primitives so that full textures are mapped on each point; false otherwise. When false, the vertex texture coordinates are used for the entire point.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.RangeFogEnable
member.summary: Gets or sets enabling of range-based vertex fog. The default value is false.
member.returns: true if range-based vertex fog is enabled; false otherwise. If false, depth-based fog is used.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ReferenceAlpha
member.summary: Specifies a reference alpha value against which pixels are tested when alpha testing is enabled. The default value is 0.
member.returns: Integer that specifies the reference alpha value to set or get. This is an 8-bit value placed in the low 8 bits of the DWORD render-state value. Values can range from 0x00000000 through 0x000000FF.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ReferenceStencil
member.summary: Specifies a reference value to use for the stencil test. The default is 0.
member.returns: Integer that specifies the stencil test value to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.ScissorTestEnable
member.summary: Enables or disables scissor testing. The default is false.
member.returns: true to enable scissor testing; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.SeparateAlphaBlendEnabled
member.summary: Enables or disables the separate blend mode for the alpha channel. The default is false.
member.returns: true to enable the separate blend mode for the alpha channel; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.SlopeScaleDepthBias
member.summary: Gets or sets a value used to determine how much bias can be applied to coplanar primitives to reduce flimmering z-fighting. The default is 0.
member.returns: Value that specifies the slope scale bias to apply.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.SourceBlend
member.summary: Gets or sets the color blending factor. This factor represents a value by which to multiply the source pixel color before adding it to the destination pixel to produce a color that is a blend of the two. The default is Blend.One.
member.returns: A Blend factor to set or get for the source pixel.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilDepthBufferFail
member.summary: Gets or sets the stencil operation to perform if the stencil test passes and the depth-test fails. The default is StencilOperation.Keep.
member.returns: The stencil operation to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilEnable
member.summary: Gets or sets stencil enabling. The default is false.
member.returns: true if stenciling is enabled; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilFail
member.summary: Gets or sets the stencil operation to perform if the stencil test fails. The default is StencilOperation.Keep.
member.returns: The stencil operation to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilFunction
member.summary: Gets or sets the comparison function for the stencil test. The default is CompareFunction.Always.
member.returns: Value of a CompareFunction that represents the comparison function to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilMask
member.summary: Gets or sets the mask applied to the reference value and each stencil buffer entry to determine the significant bits for the stencil test. The default mask is Int32.MaxValue.
member.returns: Value that represents the mask to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilPass
member.summary: Gets or sets the stencil operation to perform if the stencil test passes. The default is StencilOperation.Keep.
member.returns: The stencil operation to perform.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.StencilWriteMask
member.summary: Gets or sets the write mask applied to values written into the stencil buffer. The default mask is Int32.MaxValue.
member.returns: Value that represents the write mask to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.TwoSidedStencilMode
member.summary: Enables or disables two-sided stenciling. The default is false.
member.returns: true to enable two-sided stenciling; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.Wrap0
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture-wrapping behavior for multiple sets of texture coordinates. The default value for this render state is TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero (wrapping disabled in all directions).
member.returns: Combination of values from TextureWrapCoordinates to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.Wrap10
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture-wrapping behavior for multiple sets of texture coordinates. The default value for this render state is TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero (wrapping disabled in all directions).
member.returns: Combination of values from TextureWrapCoordinates to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.Wrap11
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture-wrapping behavior for multiple sets of texture coordinates. The default value for this render state is TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero (wrapping disabled in all directions).
member.returns: Combination of values from TextureWrapCoordinates to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.Wrap12
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture-wrapping behavior for multiple sets of texture coordinates. The default value for this render state is TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero (wrapping disabled in all directions).
member.returns: Combination of values from TextureWrapCoordinates to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.Wrap13
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture-wrapping behavior for multiple sets of texture coordinates. The default value for this render state is TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero (wrapping disabled in all directions).
member.returns: Combination of values from TextureWrapCoordinates to set or get.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderState.Wrap14
member.summary: Gets or sets the texture-wrapping behavior for multiple sets of texture coordinates. The default value for this render state is TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero (wrapping disabled in all directions).
member.returns: Combination of values from TextureWrapCoordinates to set or get.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget
member.summary: Represents a resource that will be written to at the end of a render pass. This is the base class for RenderTarget2D and RenderTargetCube.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget2D.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of this class.
member.param: The graphics device to associate with this render target resource.
Width, in pixels, of the render target. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferWidth to get the current screen width.
Height, in pixels, of the render target. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.BackBufferHeight to get the current screen height.

The number of downsampled surfaces to create when preprocessing the texture. These smaller versions of the texture, known as mip levels, are used when the texture is minified to fit a smaller area than the original texture size. The chain of downsampled surfaces associated with a texture is sometimes called a mipmap chain. If this is zero, all texture sublevels down to 11 pixels will be generated for hardware that supports mipmapped textures.
Surface format of the render target. Use GraphicsAdapter.CheckDeviceFormat to determine if a particular surface format is usable in a render target.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTarget2D(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.MultiSampleType,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage) with the specified values.

Surface format of the render target. Use GraphicsAdapter.CheckDeviceFormat to determine if a particular surface format is usable in a render target.
The levels of full-scene multisampling that the device can apply. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleType to get the MultiSampleType of the back buffer.
The number of quality stops available for a given multisample type. You can use graphicsDevice.PresentationParameters.MultiSampleQuality to get the multisample quality of the back buffer.
Options identifying the behaviors of this render target resource.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ResolveTexture2D.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat)
member.summary: Initializes an empty instance of Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ResolveTexture2D(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat).
member.param: The GraphicsDevice used to display the texture.

The width of the texture, in pixels. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. If this value is 0, width is set to 1.

The height of the texture, in pixels. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. If this value is 0, height is set to 1.

The number of downsampled surfaces to create when preprocessing the texture. These smaller versions of the texture, known as mip levels, are used when the texture is minified to fit a smaller area than the original texture size. The chain of downsampled surfaces associated with a texture is sometimes called a mipmap chain.If numberLevels is zero, all texture sublevels down to 11 pixels will be generated for hardware that supports mipmapped textures. Use Texture.LevelCount to see the number of levels generated.

A SurfaceFormat value specifying the requested pixel format for the texture. The returned texture may be of a different format if the device does not support the requested format. Applications should check the format of the returned texture to ensure that it matches the requested format.

member.summary: Adds a sprite string to the batch of sprites to be rendered, specifying the font, output text, screen position, and color tint.
member.param: The sprite font.
The string to draw.
The location, in screen coordinates, where the text will be drawn.
The desired color of the text.

member.summary: Adds a sprite string to the batch of sprites to be rendered, specifying the font, output text, screen position, color tint, rotation, origin, scale, and effects.
member.param: The sprite font.
The string to draw.
The location, in screen coordinates, where the text will be drawn.
The desired color of the text.
The angle, in radians, to rotate the text around the origin.
The origin of the string. Specify (0,0) for the upper-left corner.
Uniform multiple by which to scale the sprite width and height.
Rotations to apply prior to rendering.
The sorting depth of the sprite, between 0 (front) and 1 (back).

member.summary: Adds a sprite string to the batch of sprites to be rendered, specifying the font, output text, screen position, color tint, rotation, origin, scale, effects, and depth.
member.param: The sprite font.
The string to draw.
The location, in screen coordinates, where the text will be drawn.
The desired color of the text.
The angle, in radians, to rotate the text around the origin.
The origin of the string. Specify (0,0) for the upper-left corner.
Vector containing separate scalar multiples for the x- and y-axes of the sprite.
Rotations to apply prior to rendering.
The sorting depth of the sprite, between 0 (front) and 1 (back).

member.summary: Adds a sprite to the batch of sprites to be rendered, specifying the texture, destination, and source rectangles, color tint, rotation, origin, effects, and sort depth.
member.param: The sprite texture.
A rectangle specifying, in screen coordinates, where the sprite will be drawn. If this rectangle is not the same size as sourceRectangle, the sprite is scaled to fit.
A rectangle specifying, in texels, which section of the rectangle to draw. Use null to draw the entire texture.
The color channel modulation to use. Use Color.White for full color with no tinting.
The angle, in radians, to rotate the sprite around the origin.
The origin of the sprite. Specify (0,0) for the upper-left corner.
Rotations to apply prior to rendering.
The sorting depth of the sprite, between 0 (front) and 1 (back).You must specify either SpriteSortMode.FrontToBack or SpriteSortMode.BackToFront for this parameter to affect sprite drawing.

The color channel modulation to use. Use Color.White for full color with no tinting.
The angle, in radians, to rotate the sprite around the origin.
The origin of the sprite. Specify (0,0) for the upper-left corner.
Uniform multiple by which to scale the sprite width and height.
Rotations to apply prior to rendering.
The sorting depth of the sprite, between 0 (front) and 1 (back).You must specify either SpriteSortMode.FrontToBack or SpriteSortMode.BackToFront for this parameter to affect sprite drawing.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture2D.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat)
member.summary: Creates an uninitialized Texture2D resource of the specified dimensions. To initialize a Texture2D from an existing file, see the static method Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load``1(System.String) or Texture2D.FromFile.
member.param: The GraphicsDevice used to display the texture.

The width of the texture, in pixels. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. If this value is 0, a value of 1 is used.

The height of the texture, in pixels. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. If this value is 0, a value of 1 is used.

The number of downsampled surfaces to create when preprocessing the texture. These smaller versions of the texture, known as mipmap levels, are used when the texture is minified to fit a smaller area than the original texture size. The chain of downsampled surfaces associated with a texture is sometimes called a mipmap chain.If numberLevels is zero, all texture sublevels down to 11 pixels will be generated for hardware that supports mipmapped textures. Use Texture.LevelCount to see the number of levels generated.
Options identifying the behaviors of this texture resource.

A SurfaceFormat value specifying the requested pixel format for the texture. The returned texture may be of a different format if the device does not support the requested format. Applications should check the format of the returned texture to ensure that it matches the requested format.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Texture3D.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat)
member.summary: Creates an uninitialized volume texture resource of the given dimensions, specifying the memory management mode for the resource. To initialize a Texture3D from an existing file, see the static method Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load``1(System.String) or Texture3D.FromFile.
member.param: The GraphicsDevice that will display the volume texture.

The width, in pixels, of the top-level of the volume texture. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. The pixel dimensions of subsequent levels will be the truncated value of half of the previous level's pixel dimension (independently). Each dimension clamps at a size of 1 pixel. Thus, if the division by two results in 0 (zero), 1 will be taken instead. The maximum dimension that a driver supports (for width, height, and depth) can be found in GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxVolumeExtent.

The height, in pixels, of the top-level of the volume texture. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. The pixel dimensions of subsequent levels will be the truncated value of half of the previous level's pixel dimension (independently). Each dimension clamps at a size of 1 pixel. Thus, if the division by two results in 0 (zero), 1 will be taken instead. The maximum dimension that a driver supports (for width, height, and depth) can be found in GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxVolumeExtent.

The depth, in pixels, of the top-level of the volume texture. This value must be a power of two if the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.TextureCaps.RequiresVolumeMapPower2 property of graphicsDevice is true. The pixel dimensions of subsequent levels will be the truncated value of half of the previous level's pixel dimension (independently). Each dimension clamps at a size of 1 pixel. Thus, if the division by two results in 0 (zero), 1 will be taken instead. The maximum dimension that a driver supports (for width, height, and depth) can be found in GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.MaxVolumeExtent.

The number of downsampled surfaces to create when preprocessing the texture. These smaller versions of the texture, known as mipmap levels, are used when the texture is minified to fit a smaller area than the original texture size. The chain of downsampled surfaces associated with a texture is sometimes called a mipmap chain.If numberLevels is zero, all texture sublevels down to 11 pixels will be generated for hardware that supports mipmapped textures. Use Texture.LevelCount to see the number of levels generated.
Options identifying the behaviors of this texture resource.
The format of all levels in the volume texture resource.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureCube.#ctor(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.GraphicsDevice,System.Int32,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat)
member.summary: Creates an uninitialized TextureCube resource of the specified dimensions. To initialize a Texture2D from an existing file, see the static method Framework.Content.ContentManager.Load``1(System.String) or TextureCube.FromFile.
member.param: The GraphicsDevice that will display the cube texture.

The size of the edges of all the top-level faces of the cube texture. The pixel dimensions of subsequent levels of each face will be the truncated value of half of the previous level's pixel dimension (independently). Each dimension clamps at a size of 1 pixel. Thus, if the division by 2 results in 0 (zero), 1 will be taken instead.

The number of downsampled surfaces to create for each face of the cube texture when preprocessing the texture. These smaller versions of the texture, known as mip levels, are used when the texture is minified to fit a smaller area than the original texture size. The chain of downsampled surfaces associated with a texture is sometimes called a mipmap chain.If numberLevels is zero, all cube texture sublevels down to 11 pixels will be generated for each face for hardware that supports mipmapped cube textures. Use Texture.LevelCount to see the number of levels generated.
A set of options identifying the behaviors of this resource.
The format of all levels in the cube texture.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BlendFunction
member.summary: Defines how to combine a source color with the destination color already on the render target for color blending.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BlendFunction.Add
member.summary: The result is the destination added to the source.Result = (Source Color * Source Blend) + (Destination Color * Destination Blend)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BlendFunction.Max
member.summary: The result is the maximum of the source and destination.Result = max( (Source Color * Source Blend), (Destination Color * Destination Blend) )

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BlendFunction.Min
member.summary: The result is the minimum of the source and destination.Result = min( (Source Color * Source Blend), (Destination Color * Destination Blend) )

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BlendFunction.ReverseSubtract
member.summary: The result is the source subtracted from the destination.Result = (Destination Color * Destination Blend) (Source Color * Source Blend)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BlendFunction.Subtract
member.summary: The result is the destination subtracted from the source.Result = (Source Color * Source Blend) (Destination Color * Destination Blend)

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend
member.summary: Defines color blending factors.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.Zero
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by (0, 0, 0, 0).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.One
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by (1, 1, 1, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.SourceColor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the source color. This can be represented as (Rs, Gs, Bs, As), where R, G, B, and A respectively stand for the red, green, blue, and alpha source values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseSourceColor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of the source color. This can be represented as (1 Rs, 1 Gs, 1 Bs, 1 As) where R, G, B, and A respectively stand for the red, green, blue, and alpha destination values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.SourceAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the alpha value of the source. This can be represented as (As, As, As, As), where As is the alpha source value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseSourceAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of the alpha value of the source. This can be represented as (1 As, 1 As, 1 As, 1 As), where As is the alpha destination value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.DestinationAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the alpha value of the destination. This can be represented as (Ad, Ad, Ad, Ad), where Ad is the destination alpha value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseDestinationAlpha
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of the alpha value of the destination. This can be represented as (1 Ad, 1 Ad, 1 Ad, 1 Ad), where Ad is the alpha destination value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.DestinationColor
member.summary: Each component color is multiplied by the destination color. This can be represented as (Rd, Gd, Bd, Ad), where R, G, B, and A respectively stand for red, green, blue, and alpha destination values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseDestinationColor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of the destination color. This can be represented as (1 Rd, 1 Gd, 1 Bd, 1 Ad), where Rd, Gd, Bd, and Ad respectively stand for the red, green, blue, and alpha destination values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.SourceAlphaSaturation
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by either the alpha of the source color, or the inverse of the alpha of the source color, whichever is greater. This can be represented as (f, f, f, 1), where f = min(A, 1 Ad).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.BothInverseSourceAlpha
member.summary: (Win32 only) Each component of the source color is multiplied by the inverse of the alpha of the source color, and each component of the destination color is multiplied by the alpha of the source color. This can be represented as (1 As, 1 As, 1 As, 1 As), with a destination blend factor of (As, As, As, As); the destination blend selection is overridden. This blend mode is supported only for the RenderState.SourceBlend render state.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.BlendFactor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by a constant set in RenderState.BlendFactor.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.InverseBlendFactor
member.summary: Each component of the color is multiplied by the inverse of a constant set in RenderState.BlendFactor. This blend mode is supported only if GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.BlendCaps.SupportsBlendFactor is true in the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.SourceBlendCapabilities or GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.DestinationBlendCapabilities properties.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.Blend.BothSourceAlpha
member.summary: This mode is obsolete. The same effect can be achieved by setting the source and destination blend factors to SourceAlpha and InverseSourceAlpha in separate calls.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BufferUsage
member.summary: Specifies special usage of the buffer contents.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BufferUsage.None
member.summary: None

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BufferUsage.Points
member.summary: Indicates that the vertex or index buffer will be used for drawing point sprites. The buffer is loaded in system memory if software vertex processing is needed to emulate point sprites.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.BufferUsage.WriteOnly
member.summary: Indicates that the application only writes to the vertex buffer. If specified, the driver chooses the best memory location for efficient writing and rendering. Attempts to read from a write-only vertex buffer fail.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ClearOptions.Target

member.summary: Defines the color channels that can be chosen for a per-channel write to a render target color buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ColorWriteChannels.All
member.summary: All buffer channels.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ColorWriteChannels.Alpha
member.summary: Alpha channel of a buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ColorWriteChannels.Blue
member.summary: Blue channel of a buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ColorWriteChannels.Green
member.summary: Green channel of a buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ColorWriteChannels.None
member.summary: No channel selected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.ColorWriteChannels.Red
member.summary: Red channel of a buffer.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction
member.summary: Defines comparison functions that can be chosen for alpha, stencil, or depth-buffer tests.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.Always
member.summary: Always pass the test.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.Equal
member.summary: Accept the new pixel if its value is equal to the value of the current pixel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.Greater
member.summary: Accept the new pixel if its value is greater than the value of the current pixel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.GreaterEqual
member.summary: Accept the new pixel if its value is greater than or equal to the value of the current pixel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.Less
member.summary: Accept the new pixel if its value is less than the value of the current pixel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.LessEqual
member.summary: Accept the new pixel if its value is less than or equal to the value of the current pixel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.Never
member.summary: Always fail the test.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompareFunction.NotEqual
member.summary: Accept the new pixel if its value does not equal the value of the current pixel.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerIncludeHandlerType
member.summary: Identifies an include file as a local or system resource.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerIncludeHandlerType.Local
member.summary: A local resource.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerIncludeHandlerType.System
member.summary: A system resource.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions
member.summary: Defines optimization options that may be chosen for shader and effect code compilation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.AvoidFlowControl
member.summary: Hints to the compiler to avoid using flow-control instructions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.Debug
member.summary: Inserts debug file name, line numbers, and type and symbol information during shader compile.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.ForcePixelShaderSoftwareNoOptimizations
member.summary: Forces the compiler to compile against the next highest available software target for pixel shaders. This flag also turns optimizations off and debugging on.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.ForceVertexShaderSoftwareNoOptimizations
member.summary: Forces the compiler to compile against the next highest available software target for vertex shaders. This flag also turns optimizations off and debugging on.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.None
member.summary: No options specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.NoPreShader
member.summary: Disables preshaders. The compiler will not pull out static expressions for evaluation on the host CPU. Additionally, the compiler will not loft any expressions when compiling stand-alone functions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.NotCloneable
member.summary: Indicates the effect will be non-cloneable and will not contain any shader binary data. Setting this flag reduces effect memory usage by about 50 percent because it eliminates the need for the effect system to keep a copy of the shaders in memory.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.PackMatrixColumnMajor
member.summary: Unless explicitly specified, matrices will be packed in column major order (each vector will be in a single column) when passed to and from the shader. This is generally more efficient because it allows vector-matrix multiplication to be performed using a series of dot products.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.PackMatrixRowMajor
member.summary: Unless explicitly specified, matrices will be packed in row major order (each vector will be in a single row) when passed to or from the shader.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.PartialPrecision
member.summary: Forces all computations in the resulting shader to occur at partial precision. This may result in faster evaluation of shaders on some hardware.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.PreferFlowControl
member.summary: Hints to the compiler to prefer using flow-control instructions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.SkipOptimization
member.summary: Instructs the compiler to skip optimization steps during code generation. Unless you are trying to isolate a problem in your code and you suspect the compiler, using this option is not recommended.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CompilerOptions.SkipValidation
member.summary: Do not validate the generated code against known capabilities and constraints. This option is recommended only when compiling shaders that are known to work (that is, shaders that have compiled before without this option). Shaders are always validated by the runtime before they are set to the device.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CubeMapFace

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CubeMapFace.NegativeY
member.summary: Negative y-face of the cube map.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CubeMapFace.NegativeZ

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CubeMapFace.PositiveX
member.summary: Positive x-face of the cube map.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CubeMapFace.PositiveY
member.summary: Positive y-face of the cube map.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CubeMapFace.PositiveZ
member.summary: Positive z-face of the cube map.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CullMode
member.summary: Defines winding orders that may be used to identify back faces for culling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CullMode.CullClockwiseFace
member.summary: Cull back faces with clockwise vertices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CullMode.CullCounterClockwiseFace
member.summary: Cull back faces with counterclockwise vertices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.CullMode.None
member.summary: Do not cull back faces.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat
member.summary: Defines the format of data in a depth buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth15Stencil1
member.summary: A 16-bit depth-buffer bit depth in which 15 bits are reserved for the depth channel and 1 bit is reserved for the stencil channel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth16
member.summary: A 16-bit depth-buffer bit depth.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth24
member.summary: A 32-bit depth-buffer bit depth that uses 24 bits for the depth channel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth24Stencil4
member.summary: A 32-bit depth-buffer bit depth that uses 24 bits for the depth channel and 4 bits for the stencil channel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth24Stencil8
member.summary: A non-lockable format that contains 24 bits of depth (in a 24-bit floating-point format 20E4) and 8 bits of stencil.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth24Stencil8Single
member.summary: A 32-bit depth-buffer bit depth that uses 24 bits for the depth channel and 8 bits for the stencil channel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Depth32
member.summary: a 32-bit depth-buffer bit depth.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DepthFormat.Unknown
member.summary: Format is unknown.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DeviceType
member.summary: Specifies the type of device driver.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DeviceType.Hardware
member.summary: A hardware device. Using the flag to get direct access to the video hardware.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DeviceType.NullReference
member.summary: A null device. This is a reference device that can do everything except render a scene.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.DeviceType.Reference
member.summary: A reference device. Use this flag to create a software emulated device.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass
member.summary: Defines classes that can be used for effect parameters or shader constants.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass.MatrixColumns
member.summary: Constant is a column major matrix.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass.MatrixRows
member.summary: Constant is a row major matrix.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass.Object
member.summary: Constant is either a texture, a shader, or a string.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass.Scalar
member.summary: Constant is a scalar.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass.Struct
member.summary: Constant is a structure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterClass.Vector
member.summary: Constant is a vector.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterType
member.summary: Defines types that can be used for effect parameters or shader constants.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterType.Bool
member.summary: Parameter is a Boolean. Any nonzero value passed in will be mapped to 1 (TRUE) before being written into the constant table; otherwise, the value will be set to 0 in the constant table.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.EffectParameterType.Int32
member.summary: Parameter is an integer. Any floating-point values passed in will be rounded off (to zero decimal places) before being written into the constant table.
