member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FillMode
member.summary: Describes options for filling the vertices and lines that define a primitive.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FillMode.Point
member.summary: Draw a point at each vertex.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FillMode.Solid
member.summary: Draw solid faces for each primitive.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FillMode.WireFrame
member.summary: Draw lines connecting the vertices that define a primitive face.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions
member.summary: Defines modes describing how to filter an image or mipmap when it is minified or magnified to fit a set of vertices.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Box
member.summary: Each pixel is computed by averaging a 22(2) box of pixels from the source image. This filter works only when the dimensions of the destination are half those of the source, as is the case with mipmaps.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Dither
member.summary: Resulting image must be dithered using a 44 ordered dither algorithm. This happens when converting from one format to another.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.DitherDiffusion
member.summary: Do diffuse dithering on the image when changing from one format to another.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Linear
member.summary: Bilinear interpolation filtering is used as a texture magnification or minification filter. A weighted average of a 22 area of texels surrounding the desired pixel is used. The texture filter to use between mipmap levels is trilinear mipmap interpolation. The rasterizer interpolates pixel color in a linear manner, using the texels of the two nearest textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Mirror
member.summary: Same as specifying the MirrorU, MirrorV, and MirrorW flags. This flag is always used internally for this function.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.MirrorU
member.summary: Pixels off the edge of the texture on the u-axis should be mirrored, not wrapped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.MirrorV
member.summary: Pixels off the edge of the texture on the v-axis should be mirrored, not wrapped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.MirrorW
member.summary: Pixels off the edge of the texture on the w-axis should be mirrored, not wrapped.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.None
member.summary: Mipmapping disabled. The rasterizer uses the magnification filter instead.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Point
member.summary: Each destination pixel is computed by sampling the nearest pixel from the source image.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Srgb
member.summary: Same as specifying SrgbIn | SrgbOut.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.SrgbIn
member.summary: Input data is in sRGB (gamma 2.2) color space.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.SrgbOut
member.summary: Output data is in sRGB (gamma 2.2) color space.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FilterOptions.Triangle
member.summary: Each pixel in the source image contributes equally to the destination image. This is the slowest of the filters.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FogMode.Exponent
member.summary: Fog effect intensifies in a linear manner between the start and end points, according to the following formula.[Image, see documentation page]

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FogMode.ExponentSquared
member.summary: Fog effect intensifies exponentially with the square of the distance, according to the following formula.[Image, see documentation page]

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FogMode.Linear
member.summary: Fog effect intensifies exponentially, according to the following formula.[Image, see documentation page]

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.FogMode.None
member.summary: No fog effect.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval
member.summary: Defines flags that describe the relationship between the adapter refresh rate and the rate at which GraphicsDevice.Present operations are completed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Default
member.summary: Equivalent to setting One.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.One
member.summary: The driver waits for the vertical retrace period (the runtime will beam trace to prevent tearing). GraphicsDevice.Present operations are not affected more frequently than the screen refresh rate; the runtime completes one GraphicsDevice.Present operation per adapter refresh period, at most. This option is always available for both windowed and full-screen swap chains.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Two
member.summary: The driver waits for the vertical retrace period. GraphicsDevice.Present operations are not affected more frequently than every second screen refresh. Check the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.PresentInterval property to determine whether the driver supports this option.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Three
member.summary: The driver waits for the vertical retrace period. GraphicsDevice.Present operations are not affected more frequently than every third screen refresh. Check the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.PresentInterval property to determine whether the driver supports this option.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Four
member.summary: The driver waits for the vertical retrace period. GraphicsDevice.Present operations are not affected more frequently than every fourth screen refresh. Check the GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.PresentInterval property to determine whether the driver supports this option.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentInterval.Immediate
member.summary: The runtime updates the window client area immediately, and might do so more than once during the adapter refresh period. GraphicsDevice.Present operations might be affected immediately. This option is always available for both windowed and full-screen swap chains.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentOptions
member.summary: Defines flags that control the behavior of the back buffer and depth buffer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentOptions.DeviceClip
member.summary: Clips a windowed GraphicsDevice.Present blit into the window client area, within the monitor screen area of the video adapter that created the Microsoft Direct3D device. This flag works only on Microsoft Windows 2000 and Windows XP.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentOptions.DiscardDepthStencil
member.summary: Enables depth-buffer discarding if set when the device or swap chain is created. When this flag is set, the contents of the depth stencil buffer are invalid after either GraphicsDevice.Present or GraphicsDevice.DepthStencilBuffer is called.Discarding depth-buffer data can increase performance and is dependent on the driver. The debug runtime enforces discarding by clearing the depth-buffer to some constant value after calling either GraphicsDevice.Present or GraphicsDevice.DepthStencilBuffer with a different depth surface.Discarding depth-buffer data is illegal for all lockable formats, DepthFormat.Depth16Lockable, and DepthFormat.D32Lockable. Using the GraphicsDevice constructor to specify a lockable format and depth-buffer discarding will result in failure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentOptions.None
member.summary: Use no presentation flags.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PresentOptions.Video
member.summary: Informs the driver that the back buffers contain video data.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType
member.summary: Defines how data in a vertex stream is interpreted during a draw call.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType.LineList
member.summary: Renders the vertices as a list of isolated straight line segments; the count may be any positive integer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType.LineStrip
member.summary: Renders the vertices as a single polyline; the count may be any positive integer.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType.PointList
member.summary: Renders the vertices as a collection of isolated points. This value is unsupported for indexed primitives.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleFan
member.summary: Renders the vertices as a triangle fan.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleList
member.summary: Renders the specified vertices as a sequence of isolated triangles. Each group of three vertices defines a separate triangle. Back-face culling is affected by the current winding-order render state.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.PrimitiveType.TriangleStrip
member.summary: Renders the vertices as a triangle strip. The back-face culling flag is flipped automatically on even-numbered triangles.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.Filter
member.summary: Query the resource format to see if it supports texture filter types other than TextureFilter.Point (which is always supported).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.None

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.PostPixelShaderBlending
member.summary: Query the resource to verify support for post pixel shader blending support, including alpha test, pixel fog, render-target blending, color write enable, and dithering.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.SrgbRead
member.summary: Query the resource to verify if a texture supports gamma correction during a read operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.SrgbWrite
member.summary: Query the resource to verify if a texture supports gamma correction during a write operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.VertexTexture
member.summary: Query the resource to verify support for vertex shader texture sampling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.QueryUsages.WrapAndMip
member.summary: Query the resource to verify support for texture wrapping and mipmapping.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage
member.summary: Determines how render target data is used once a new render target is set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.DiscardContents
member.summary: Always clears the render target data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.PlatformContents
member.summary: Either clears or keeps the data, depending on the current platform. On Xbox 360, the render target will discard contents. On PC, the render target will discard if multisampling is enabled, and preserve the contents if not.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.RenderTargetUsage.PreserveContents
member.summary: Always keeps the render target data.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SaveStateMode
member.summary: Defines options for saving the graphics device state before and after an effect technique is applied.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SaveStateMode.None
member.summary: No device state is saved when calling Effect.Begin or restored when calling Effect.End.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SaveStateMode.SaveState
member.summary: Save all device state when calling Effect.Begin and restore device state when calling Effect.End.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SetDataOptions
member.summary: Describes whether existing buffer data will be overwritten or discarded during a SetData operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SetDataOptions.Discard
member.summary: The SetData operation will discard all existing buffer data.The operation will overwrite (with a write-only operation) every location within the locked surface. This is a valid option when using dynamic textures, dynamic vertex buffers, and dynamic index buffers. You may not use this option to update a portion of a surface.For vertex and index buffers, the SetData operation will discard the entire buffer. A pointer to a new memory area is returned so that the direct memory access (DMA) and rendering from the previous area do not stall.For textures, the SetData operation will overwrite (with a write-only operation) every location within the region being locked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SetDataOptions.None
member.summary: Portions of existing data in the buffer may be overwritten during this operation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SetDataOptions.NoOverwrite
member.summary: The SetData operation will not overwrite existing data in the vertex and index buffers. Specifying this option allows the driver to return immediately from a SetData operation and continue rendering.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteBlendMode
member.summary: The following flags are used to specify sprite blending rendering options to the flags parameter in SpriteBatch.Begin:

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteBlendMode.Additive
member.summary: Enable additive blending.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteBlendMode.AlphaBlend
member.summary: Enable alpha blending.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteBlendMode.None
member.summary: No blending specified.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteEffects
member.summary: Defines sprite rotation options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteEffects.FlipHorizontally
member.summary: Rotate 180 degrees about the Y axis before rendering.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteEffects.FlipVertically
member.summary: Rotate 180 degrees about the X axis before rendering.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteEffects.None
member.summary: No rotations specified.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode
member.summary: Defines sprite sort-rendering options.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.BackToFront
member.summary: Same as Deferred mode, except sprites are sorted by depth in back-to-front order prior to drawing. This procedure is recommended when drawing transparent sprites of varying depths.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.Deferred
member.summary: Sprites are not drawn until SpriteBatch.End is called. SpriteBatch.End will apply graphics device settings and draw all the sprites in one batch, in the same order calls to SpriteBatch.Draw were received. This mode allows SpriteBatch.Draw calls to two or more instances of SpriteBatch without introducing conflicting graphics device settings. SpriteBatch defaults to Deferred mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.FrontToBack
member.summary: Same as Deferred mode, except sprites are sorted by depth in front-to-back order prior to drawing. This procedure is recommended when drawing opaque sprites of varying depths.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.Immediate
member.summary: SpriteBatch.Begin will apply new graphics device settings, and sprites will be drawn within each SpriteBatch.Draw call. In Immediate mode there can only be one active SpriteBatch instance without introducing conflicting device settings. Immediate mode is faster than Deferred mode.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SpriteSortMode.Texture
member.summary: Same as Deferred mode, except sprites are sorted by texture prior to drawing. This can improve performance when drawing non-overlapping sprites of uniform depth.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation
member.summary: Defines stencil buffer operations.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.Decrement
member.summary: Decrements the stencil-buffer entry, wrapping to the maximum value if the new value is less than 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.DecrementSaturation
member.summary: Decrements the stencil-buffer entry, clamping to 0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.Increment
member.summary: Increments the stencil-buffer entry, wrapping to 0 if the new value exceeds the maximum value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.IncrementSaturation
member.summary: Increments the stencil-buffer entry, clamping to the maximum value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.Invert
member.summary: Inverts the bits in the stencil-buffer entry.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.Keep
member.summary: Does not update the stencil-buffer entry. This is the default value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.Replace
member.summary: Replaces the stencil-buffer entry with a reference value.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.StencilOperation.Zero
member.summary: Sets the stencil-buffer entry to 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat
member.summary: Defines various types of surface formats.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Alpha8
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 8-bit alpha only.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr233
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 8-bit BGR texture format using 2 bits for blue, 3 bits for green, and 3 bits for red.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr24
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 24-bit BGR pixel format with 8 bits per channel.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr32
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 32-bit BGR pixel format, where 8 bits are reserved for each color.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr444
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 16-bit BGR pixel format where 4 bits are reserved for each color.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr555
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 16-bit BGR pixel format where 5 bits are reserved for each color.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgr565
member.summary: (Unsigned format) 16-bit BGR pixel format with 5 bits for blue, 6 bits for green, and 5 bits for red.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Bgra1010102

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Color

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Depth15Stencil1

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Depth24

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Depth24Stencil4

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Depth24Stencil8

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Depth24Stencil8Single

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Depth32

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Dxt1
member.summary: DXT1 compression texture format. The runtime will not allow an application to create a surface using a DXTn format unless the surface dimensions are multiples of 4. This applies to offscreen-plain surfaces, render targets, 2D textures, cube textures, and volume textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Dxt2
member.summary: DXT2 compression texture format. The runtime will not allow an application to create a surface using a DXTn format unless the surface dimensions are multiples of 4. This applies to offscreen-plain surfaces, render targets, 2D textures, cube textures, and volume textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Dxt3
member.summary: DXT3 compression texture format. The runtime will not allow an application to create a surface using a DXTn format unless the surface dimensions are multiples of 4. This applies to offscreen-plain surfaces, render targets, 2D textures, cube textures, and volume textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Dxt4
member.summary: DXT4 compression texture format. The runtime will not allow an application to create a surface using a DXTn format unless the surface dimensions are multiples of 4. This applies to offscreen-plain surfaces, render targets, 2D textures, cube textures, and volume textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Dxt5
member.summary: DXT5 compression texture format. The runtime will not allow an application to create a surface using a DXTn format unless the surface dimensions are multiples of 4. This applies to offscreen-plain surfaces, render targets, 2D textures, cube textures, and volume textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.HalfVector2

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.HalfVector4

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.Multi2Bgra32

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.NormalizedAlpha1010102

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.NormalizedByte2Computed

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.VideoGrGb
member.summary: A 16-bit packed RGB format analogous to VideoYuYv (U0Y0, V0Y1, U2Y2, and so on). It requires a pixel pair to properly represent the color value. The first pixel in the pair contains 8 bits of green (in the low 8 bits) and 8 bits of red (in the high 8 bits). The second pixel contains 8 bits of green (in the low 8 bits) and 8 bits of blue (in the high 8 bits). Together, the two pixels share the red and blue components, while each has a unique green component (R0G0, B0G1, R2G2, and so on). The texture sampler does not normalize the colors when looking up into a pixel shader; they remain in the range of 0.0f to 255.0f. This is true for all programmable pixel shader models. For the fixed-function pixel shader, the hardware should normalize to the 0.f to 1.f range and essentially treat it as the VideoUyVy texture. Hardware that exposes this format must have GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.PixelShader1xMaxValue set to a value capable of handling that range.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.VideoRgBg
member.summary: A 16-bit packed RGB format analogous to VideoUyVy (Y0U0, Y1V0, Y2U2, and so on). It requires a pixel pair to properly represent the color value. The first pixel in the pair contains 8 bits of green (in the high 8 bits) and 8 bits of red (in the low 8 bits). The second pixel contains 8 bits of green (in the high 8 bits) and 8 bits of blue (in the low 8 bits). Together, the two pixels share the red and blue components, while each has a unique green component (G0R0, G1B0, G2R2, and so on). The texture sampler does not normalize the colors when looking up into a pixel shader; they remain in the range of 0.0f to 255.0f. This is true for all programmable pixel shader models. For the fixed-function pixel shader, the hardware should normalize to the 0.f to 1.f range and essentially treat it as the VideoUyVy texture. Hardware that exposes this format must have GraphicsDeviceCapabilities.PixelShader1xMaxValue set to a value capable of handling that range.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.VideoUyVy
member.summary: YUY2 format (PC98 compliance)

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SurfaceFormat.VideoYuYv
member.summary: VideoYuYv format (PC98 compliance)

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SwapEffect
member.summary: Defines how the device front buffer and back buffer are to be swapped when GraphicsDevice.Present is called.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SwapEffect.Copy
member.summary: This swap effect can be specified only for a swap chain that comprises a single back buffer.Whether the swap chain is windowed or full-screen, the runtime guarantees the semantics implied by a copy-based GraphicsDevice.Present operation; specifically, that the operation leaves the content of the back buffer unchanged, instead of replacing it with the content of the front buffer as a flip-based GraphicsDevice.Present operation would.For a windowed swap chain, a GraphicsDevice.Present operation causes the back buffer content to be copied immediately to the client area of the target window. No attempt is made to synchronize the copy with the vertical retrace period of the display adapter, so tearing effects may be observed.For a full-screen swap chain, the runtime uses a combination of flip and copy operations, which are supported by hidden back buffers if necessary, to accomplish the GraphicsDevice.Present operation. Accordingly, the presentation is synchronized with the display adapter's vertical retrace and its rate is constrained by the chosen presentation interval. A swap chain specified with the PresentInterval.Immediate flag is the only exception. (For more information, see PresentationParameters.PresentationInterval.) In this case, a GraphicsDevice.Present operation copies the back buffer content directly to the front buffer without waiting for the vertical retrace.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SwapEffect.Default
member.summary: The default swap effect is Discard.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SwapEffect.Discard
member.summary: When a swap chain is created with a swap effect of Flip or Copy, the runtime guarantees that a GraphicsDevice.Present operation will not affect the content of any of the back buffers. However, meeting this guarantee can involve substantial video memory or processing overheads, especially when implementing flip semantics for a windowed swap chain or copy semantics for a full-screen swap chain.An application can use the Discard swap effect to avoid these overheads and to enable the display driver to choose the most efficient presentation technique for the swap chain.Discard is also the only swap effect that can be used when specifying a value other than None for PresentationParameters.MultiSampleType. Like a swap chain that uses Flip, a swap chain that uses Discard might include more than one back buffer.The swap chain is essentially a queue where 0 always indexes the back buffer that will be displayed by the next GraphicsDevice.Present operation and from which buffers are discarded once they have been displayed. An application that uses this swap effect should update an entire back buffer before invoking a GraphicsDevice.Present operation that displays it.The debug version of the runtime overwrites the contents of discarded back buffers with random data, to enable developers to verify that their applications are updating the entire back buffer surface correctly.For a full-screen swap chain, the presentation rate is determined by the value assigned to PresentationParameters.PresentationInterval when the device or swap chain is created. Unless this value is PresentInterval.Immediate, the presentation is synchronized with the vertical sync of the monitor. For a windowed swap chain, the presentation is implemented by means of copy operations, and always occurs immediately.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.SwapEffect.Flip
member.summary: The swap chain might include multiple back buffers and is essentially a circular queue that includes the front buffer. Within this queue, the back buffers are always numbered sequentially from 0 to (n - 1), where n is the number of back buffers, so that 0 denotes the least recently presented buffer. When GraphicsDevice.Present is invoked, the queue is rotated so that the front buffer becomes the back buffer (n - 1), while the back buffer 0 becomes the new front buffer.For a full-screen swap chain, the presentation rate is determined by the value assigned to the PresentationParameters.PresentationInterval when the device or swap chain is created. Unless this value is PresentInterval.Immediate, the presentation is synchronized with the vertical sync of the monitor.For a windowed swap chain, the flipping is implemented by means of copy operations, and the presentation always occurs immediately.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureAddressMode
member.summary: Defines constants that describe supported texture-addressing modes.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureAddressMode.Border
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the border color.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureAddressMode.Clamp
member.summary: Texture coordinates outside the range [0.0, 1.0] are set to the texture color at 0.0 or 1.0, respectively.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureAddressMode.Mirror
member.summary: Similar to Wrap, except that the texture is flipped at every integer junction. For u values between 0 and 1, for example, the texture is addressed normally; between 1 and 2, the texture is flipped (mirrored); between 2 and 3, the texture is normal again, and so on.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureAddressMode.MirrorOnce
member.summary: Similar to Mirror and Clamp. Takes the absolute value of the texture coordinate (thus, mirroring around 0), and then clamps to the maximum value. The most common usage is for volume textures, where support for the full MirrorOnce texture-addressing mode is not necessary, but the data is symmetrical around the one axis.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureAddressMode.Wrap
member.summary: Tile the texture at every integer junction. For example, for u values between 0 and 3, the texture is repeated three times; no mirroring is performed.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter
member.summary: Defines how a texture will be filtered as it is minified for each mipmap level.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter.Anisotropic
member.summary: Anisotropic texture filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. This type of filtering compensates for distortion caused by the difference in angle between the texture polygon and the plane of the screen.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter.GaussianQuad
member.summary: A 4-sample Gaussian filter used as a texture magnification or minification filter.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter.Linear
member.summary: Bilinear interpolation filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. A weighted average of a 22 area of texels surrounding the desired pixel is used. The texture filter used between mipmap levels is trilinear mipmap interpolation, in which the rasterizer performs linear interpolation on pixel color, using the texels of the two nearest mipmap textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter.None
member.summary: Mipmapping disabled. The rasterizer uses the magnification filter instead.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter.Point
member.summary: Point filtering used as a texture magnification or minification filter. The texel with coordinates nearest to the desired pixel value is used. The texture filter used between mipmap levels is based on the nearest point; that is, the rasterizer uses the color from the texel of the nearest mipmap texture.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureFilter.PyramidalQuad
member.summary: A 4-sample tent filter used as a texture magnification or minification filter.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage
member.summary: Specifies special usage of the texture data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage.AutoGenerateMipMap
member.summary: The resource automatically generates mipmaps. Automatic generation of mipmaps is not supported for volume textures and depth stencil surfaces/textures.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage.Linear
member.summary: (Xbox 360 only) Linear texture memory format. Linear formats are arranged in memory using a left-to-right and top-to-bottom layout (with pixels contiguous in memory for each row, and rows contiguous except for possible alignment padding). Use this format when doing dynamic CPU updates to textures where:You do not want the overhead of translating tile addresses using the CPU.Textures are not often referenced during the frame.Less efficient GPU performance is not a problem.This flag is valid only for texture creation on Xbox 360. It is ignored if used elsewhere. On Xbox, most formats are created as Tiled if it is applicable.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage.None
member.summary: None.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureUsage.Tiled
member.summary: (Xbox 360 only) Tiled texture memory format. Tiled formats are arranged using a memory layout designed to maximize the cache coherency of texture fetches and balance the access workload of the memory controllers. The exact pixel arrangement of tiled formats varies based on the bit depth of the format; however, pixels that are close to one another spatially are located close to one another in memory. For example, two pixels adjacent to one another in a vertical column would be separated in memory by an entire row of pixels for a linear format, but could be separated by only a few bytes for a tiled format. The tiled texture format is usually more efficient than the linear texture format.This flag is valid only when used for texture creation on Xbox 360, and will be ignored if used elsewhere. On Xbox, most formats are created as Tiled if it is applicable.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureWrapCoordinates
member.summary: Defines supported wrap coordinates.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureWrapCoordinates.None
member.summary: No texture wrap coordinates specified.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureWrapCoordinates.Zero
member.summary: U texture wrapping (wrapping in the direction of the first dimension).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureWrapCoordinates.One
member.summary: V texture wrapping (wrapping in the direction of the second dimension).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureWrapCoordinates.Two
member.summary: W texture wrapping (wrapping in the direction of the third dimension).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.TextureWrapCoordinates.Three
member.summary: Texture wrapping in the direction of the fourth dimension.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat
member.summary: Defines vertex element formats.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Single
member.summary: Single-component, 32-bit floating-point, expanded to (float, 0, 0, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Vector2
member.summary: Two-component, 32-bit floating-point, expanded to (float, Float32 value, 0, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Vector3
member.summary: Three-component, 32-bit floating point, expanded to (float, float, float, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Vector4
member.summary: Four-component, 32-bit floating point, expanded to (float, float, float, float).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.HalfVector2
member.summary: Two-component, 16-bit floating point expanded to (value, value, value, value). This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.HalfVector4
member.summary: Four-component, 16-bit floating-point expanded to (value, value, value, value). This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Rgba64
member.summary: Normalized, four-component, unsigned short, expanded to (first byte/65535.0, second byte/65535.0, third byte/65535.0, fourth byte/65535.0). This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Color
member.summary: Four-component, packed, unsigned byte, mapped to 0 to 1 range. Input is in Int32 format (ARGB) expanded to (R, G, B, A).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Rgba32
member.summary: Four-component byte with each byte normalized by dividing the component with 255.0f. This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Rg32
member.summary: Normalized, two-component, unsigned short, expanded to (first byte/65535.0, second byte/65535.0, 0, 1). This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.NormalizedShort2
member.summary: Normalized, two-component, signed short, expanded to (first short/32767.0, second short/32767.0, 0, 1). This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.NormalizedShort4
member.summary: Normalized, four-component, signed short, expanded to (first short/32767.0, second short/32767.0, third short/32767.0, fourth short/32767.0). This type is valid for vertex shader version 2.0 or higher.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Normalized101010
member.summary: Three-component, signed, 10 10 10 format normalized and expanded to (v[0]/511.0, v[1]/511.0, v[2]/511.0, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Short2
member.summary: Two-component, signed short expanded to (value, value, 0, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Short4
member.summary: Four-component, signed short expanded to (value, value, value, value).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Byte4
member.summary: Four-component, unsigned byte.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.UInt101010
member.summary: Three-component, unsigned, 10 10 10 format expanded to (value, value, value, 1).

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementFormat.Unused
member.summary: Type field in the declaration is unused. This is designed for use with VertexElementMethod.UV and VertexElementMethod.LookUpPresampled.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementMethod
member.summary: Defines the tessellator processing method for a vertex element.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementMethod.Default
member.summary: Default value. The tessellator copies the vertex data (or the spline data if it is operating on a patch) without performing additional calculations on it. The input and output types can be any value. When the tessellator is used, this element is interpolated; otherwise, vertex data is copied into the input register.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementMethod.LookUp
member.summary: Looks up a displacement map. The input type can be VertexElementFormat.Vector2, VertexElementFormat.Vector3, or VertexElementFormat.Vector4. Only the .x and .y components are used for the texture map lookup. The output type is always VertexElementFormat.Single. The device must support displacement mapping. This constant is supported only by the programmable pipeline on N-patch data, if N-patches are enabled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementMethod.LookUpPresampled
member.summary: Looks up a presampled displacement map. The input type must be set to VertexElementFormat.Unused, and the stream index and stream offset must be set to 0. The output type for this operation is always VertexElementFormat.Single. The device must support displacement mapping. This constant is supported only by the programmable pipeline on N-patch data, if N-patches are enabled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementMethod.UV
member.summary: Copies out the u and v values at a point on the rectangle or triangle patch. This results in a 2D float. The input type must be set to VertexElementFormat.Unused; the output type is always VertexElementFormat.Vector2. The input stream and offset also are unused, but must be set to 0.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage
member.summary: Defines usage for vertex elements.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Binormal
member.summary: Vertex binormal data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.BlendIndices
member.summary: Blending indices data. (BlendIndices with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies matrix indices for fixed-function vertex processing using indexed paletted skinning.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.BlendWeight
member.summary: Blending weight data. (BlendWeight with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies the blend weights in fixed-function vertex processing.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Color
member.summary: Vertex data contains diffuse or specular color. (Color with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies the diffuse color in the fixed-function vertex shader and in pixel shaders prior to ps_3_0. (Color with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 1) specifies the specular color in the fixed-function vertex shader and in pixel shaders prior to ps_3_0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Depth
member.summary: Vertex data contains depth data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Fog
member.summary: Vertex data contains fog data. (Fog with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies a fog blend value to use after pixel shading is finished. This flag applies to pixel shaders prior to version ps_3_0.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Normal
member.summary: Vertex normal data. (Normal with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies vertex normals for fixed-function vertex processing and the N-patch tessellator. (Normal with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 1) specifies vertex normals for fixed-function vertex processing for skinning.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.PointSize
member.summary: Point size data. (PointSize with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies the point-size attribute used by the setup engine of the rasterizer to expand a point into a quad for the point-sprite functionality.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Position
member.summary: Position data. (Position with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0 ) specifies the nontransformed position in fixed-function vertex processing and the N-patch tessellator. (Position with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 1) specifies the nontransformed position in the fixed-function vertex shader for skinning.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Sample
member.summary: Vertex data contains sampler data. (Sample with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies the displacement value to look up. This flag can be used only with VertexElementMethod.LookUpPresampled or VertexElementMethod.LookUp.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.Tangent
member.summary: Vertex tangent data.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.TessellateFactor
member.summary: Single, positive floating-point value. (TessellateFactor with VertexElement.UsageIndex = 0) specifies a tessellation factor used in the tessellation unit to control the rate of tessellation.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Graphics.VertexElementUsage.TextureCoordinate
member.summary: Texture coordinate data. (TextureCoordinate, n) specifies texture coordinates in fixed-function vertex processing and in pixel shaders prior to ps_3_0. These coordinates can be used to pass user-defined data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePad.SetVibration(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.PlayerIndex,System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Sets the vibration motor speeds on an Xbox 360 Controller.
member.param: Player index that identifies the controller to set.
The speed of the left motor, between 0.0 and 1.0. This motor is a low-frequency motor.
The speed of the right motor, between 0.0 and 1.0. This motor is a high-frequency motor.
member.returns: true if the vibration motors were successfully set; false if the controller was unable to process the request.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePadDeadZone
member.summary: Specifies a type of dead zone processing to apply to Xbox 360 controller analog sticks when calling GamePad.GetState.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePadDeadZone.Circular
member.summary: The combined X and Y position of each stick is compared against the dead zone. This provides better control than IndependentAxes when the stick is used as a two-dimensional control surface, such as when controlling a character's view in a first-person game.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePadDeadZone.IndependentAxes
member.summary: The X and Y positions of each stick are compared against the dead zone independently. This setting is the default when calling GamePad.GetState.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePadDeadZone.None
member.summary: The values of each stick are not processed and are returned by GamePad.GetState as "raw" values. This is best if you intend to implement your own dead zone processing.

member.summary: Starts hosting a new multiplayer session.

Maximum number of local players on the same gaming machine in this network session.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSession.BeginFind(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionType,System.Int32,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionProperties,System.AsyncCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Starts a matchmaking query to search for available multiplayer sessions.
member.param: Type of session being searched for.
Maximum number of local players on the same gaming machine in this network session.

Optional session properties to match during the search. If this argument is null, the query results will not be filtered based on the session properties of available sessions. If any of the search property values in searchProperties are specified, only sessions with matching properties will be returned by the query. null items in the searchProperties collection will match to any value for that session property.
The method to be called once the asynchronous operation has finished.
State of the asynchronous operation.
member.returns: An System.IAsyncResult used to track the progress of the method.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.QualityOfService.AverageRoundtripTime
member.summary: Gets the average (median) round trip time of all the network packets that were sent during the quality of service measurement process.
member.returns: The average (median) round trip time of all the network packets that were sent during the quality of service measurement process. Will return zero if the query has not yet completed. You can check if the query is complete using QualityOfService.IsAvailable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.QualityOfService.BytesPerSecondDownstream
member.summary: Gets an estimate of the available downstream network bandwidth from the session host to this machine, measured in bytes per second.
member.returns: An estimate of the available downstream network bandwidth from the session host to this machine, measured in bytes per second. Will return zero if the query has not yet completed. You can check if the query is complete using QualityOfService.IsAvailable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.QualityOfService.BytesPerSecondUpstream
member.summary: Gets an estimate of the available upstream network bandwidth from this machine to the session host, measured in bytes per second.
member.returns: An estimate of the available upstream network bandwidth from this machine to the session host, measured in bytes per second. Will return zero if the query has not yet completed. You can check if the query is complete using QualityOfService.IsAvailable.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.QualityOfService.IsAvailable
member.summary: Checks whether this quality of service operation has completed.
member.returns: true if quality of service data is available; false otherwise.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.QualityOfService.MinimumRoundtripTime
member.summary: Gets the minimum round trip time of any network packet that was sent during the quality of service measurement process.
member.returns: The minimum round trip time of any network packet that was sent during the quality of service measurement process. Will return zero if the query has not yet completed. You can check if the query is complete using QualityOfService.IsAvailable.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.QualityOfService
member.summary: Describes the quality of the network connection between this machine and the host of a multiplayer session that was discovered with a matchmaking query.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionEndReason
member.summary: Defines the reason a session ended.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionEndReason.ClientSignedOut
member.summary: This client player has signed out of session.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionEndReason.HostEndedSession
member.summary: The host left the session, removing all active players.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionEndReason.RemovedByHost
member.summary: The host removed this client player from the session.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionEndReason.Disconnected
member.summary: Network connectivity problems ended the session

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionJoinError
member.summary: Contains additional data about a NetworkSessionJoinException.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionJoinError.SessionNotFound
member.summary: The session could not be found.Occurs if the session has ended after the matchmaking query but before the client joined, of if there is no network connectivity between the client and session host machines.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionJoinError.SessionNotJoinable
member.summary: The session exists but is not joinable.Occurs if the session is in progress but does not allow gamers to join a session in progress.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionJoinError.SessionFull
member.summary: The session exists but does not have any open slots for local signed-in gamers.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionState
member.summary: Defines the different states of a multiplayer session.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionState.Lobby
member.summary: The local machine joins the session, waiting in the pregame lobby. The GameStarted event is raised when gameplay begins.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionState.Playing
member.summary: The local machine joins the session, currently in the middle of gameplay. The GameEnded event is raised when the session returns to the lobby.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionState.Ended
member.summary: The local machine has left the current session or the session has ended. The SessionEnded event is raised at this time. The event's arguments describe the reason for the session ending.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionType
member.summary: Defines the different types of a multiplayer session.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionType.Local
member.summary: Does not involve any networking traffic but can be used for split-screen gaming on a single Xbox 360 console.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionType.SystemLink
member.summary: Connect multiple Xbox 360 consoles or computers over a local subnet. These machines do not require a connection to Xbox LIVE or any LIVE accounts. However, connection to machines on different subnets is not allowed.If you are a Creators Club developer testing your game, you can use this type to connect an Xbox 360 console to a computer. However, cross-platform networking is not supported in games distributed to nonCreators Club community players.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionType.PlayerMatch
member.summary: Uses the Xbox LIVE matchmaking servers. This enables connection to other machines over the Internet.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.NetworkSessionType.Ranked
member.summary: All session matches are ranked. This option is available only for commercial games that have passed Xbox LIVE certification. Due to the competitive nature of the gameplay, this session type does not support join-in-progress.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.SendDataOptions
member.summary: Defines options for network packet transmission.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.SendDataOptions.None
member.summary: Sends the data with no guarantees.Packets of this type may be delivered in any order, with occasional packet loss.This is the most efficient option in terms of network bandwidth and machine resource usage. However, it is recommended only in situations where your game can recover from occasional packet loss.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.SendDataOptions.Reliable
member.summary: Sends the data with reliable delivery but no special ordering.Packets of this type are resent until arrival at the destination but may arrive out of order.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.SendDataOptions.InOrder
member.summary: Sends the data with guaranteed ordering but without reliable delivery.Occasionally, packets of this type are not delivered. However, any delivered packets always arrive in the order they were sent.Use this option in situations where the transmitted value changes constantly but old versions never arrive after a more recent version.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Net.SendDataOptions.ReliableInOrder
member.summary: Sends the data with reliability and arrival in the order originally sent.Packets of this type are resent until arrival and ordered internally so they arrive in the same order they were sent.In terms of network bandwidth usage, this is the strongest and most expensive option. Use this only when arrival and ordering are essential. Commonly, a game uses this option for a small percentage of packets. The majority of gameplay data is sent using None or Reliable.
